channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Indian State Bans Possession and Sale of Beef
item.description: Maharashtra, which includes Mumbai, is the latest Indian state to issue such bans, imposing penalties of up to five years in prison or a fine for violations.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI

item.title: France Faulted for Not Banning Corporal Punishment
item.description: The Council of Europe’s ruling, a symbolic one, has revived a debate in France, which forbids physical discipline in schools but not in family settings.
item.dc:creator: By AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Broadcast of India Gang Rape Documentary Is Banned by Court
item.description: The film, “India’s Daughter,” features an interview with Mukesh Singh, now on death row for the crime.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Countries Questioning Indonesia’s Push to Execute Drug Offenders
item.description: With six convicts put to death in January, and 10 more set to be executed soon, countries like Australia, Brazil and the Netherlands are questioning the harsh policy.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Andrew Chan and, behind, Myuran Sukumaran, in 2006, were said to have been flown to an island where people are executed.

item.title: France Seeks 3 Suspects in 1982 Attack on Goldenberg Restaurant
item.description: Unidentified assailants fired machine guns and hurled a grenade into a lunchtime crowd at a Paris deli, killing six people and wounding 22 others.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Failure to find the perpetrators of the 1982 attack on the Goldenberg restaurant in Paris has been a source of frustration for law enforcement officers and the local Jewish community alike.

item.title: Trickle of Liberian Children Returning to School Reflects Lingering Ebola Fears
item.description: Ebola cases have receded into the single digits in Liberia, but fear of the virus and a depressed economy have dampened a back-to-school campaign.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Miatta Fahnbulleh, the mother of the boy with the pink mittens, James Nyema, used to send him to a private school.

item.title: Iraqis Plan to Take Lead in Driving ISIS From Mosul
item.description: Amid concerns about Iranian involvement in the offensive against the Islamic State, the Iraqi defense minister said the Mosul mission would be “planned, timed and executed by Iraqis.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Putin Says Boris Nemtsov’s ‘Brazen Murder’ Was Politically Motivated
item.description: The Russian president, speaking about the death of Mr. Nemtsov, a Kremlin critic, for the first time, called on law enforcement agencies to stop crimes tied to politics.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: John Kerry Flies to Saudi Arabia to Discuss Iran Nuclear Talks
item.description: Mr. Kerry plans to meet with King Salman and to consult with foreign ministers from Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry during a break in the negotiations over Iran's nuclear program in Switzerland on Wednesday.

item.title: News Analysis: In Speech, Netanyahu Eased Demand for ‘Zero’ Iran Nuclear Capacity
item.description: The stances of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and President Obama remain far apart, but the Israeli leader’s remarks did raise the question of whether he could ultimately accept an imperfect deal.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Vote Nearing, Netanyahu Takes Up Familiar Cause: Iran’s Nuclear Quest
item.description: Supporters say Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is playing his strong card, but opponents say he is scaring voters while offering few hopeful solutions.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How China Fuels Myanmar’s Wars
item.description: Chinese-led development projects stoke ethnic tensions across the border.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW SMITH

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Romania’s Anti-Corruption Mania
item.description: Populist clamor against graft has turned necessary reform into prosecutorial zealotry.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK BASHAM

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Xi Jinping’s ‘Four Comprehensives’ Give Shape to a Crowded Agenda
item.description: President Xi Jinping’s “Four Comprehensives,” praised lavishly by state-run media, shows how party messages are crafted with vagueness to give an aura of grandeur to the business of ruling.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Dec. 23.

item.title: Snowden Seeks to Return Home to U.S., His Lawyer Says
item.description: The lawyer said he was working with a team of Americans and Germans on legal issues that would allow for the former intelligence contractor’s return.
item.dc:creator: By ALEXANDRA ODYNOVA

item.title: Deadly Blast Rocks Coal Mine in East Ukraine
item.description: Several miners were killed in the explosion, and dozens more were trapped underground and feared dead.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Lens Blog: Photos Hopscotch Through Cortázar’s Paris
item.description: For the centennial of Julio Cortázar’s birth, Hugo Passarello took portraits of the Argentine’s writer’s fans and friends in Paris, the setting of his novel “Hopscotch.”
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW BORYGA
item.media:description: Luisa Valenzuela. Writer. Argentine. Chosen fragment: “And while somebody explains something as always, I don’t know why I am in this café, in all cafés, in the Elephant & Castle, in the Dupont Barbès, in the Sacher, in the Pedrocchi, in the Gijón, in the Greco. ...”

item.title: Countries Questioning Indonesia’s Push to Execute Drug Offenders
item.description: With six convicts put to death in January, and 10 more set to be executed soon, countries like Australia, Brazil and the Netherlands are questioning the harsh policy.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Andrew Chan and, behind, Myuran Sukumaran, in 2006, were said to have been flown to an island where people are executed.

item.title: China’s Military Budget Increasing 10% for 2015, Official Says
item.description: A legislative spokeswoman has estimated that military spending will expand at a rate faster than the overall Chinese economy.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: In Congress, Netanyahu Faults ‘Bad Deal’ on Iran Nuclear Program
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said that negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program were proceeding on a false hope that Iran is acting in good faith. President Obama dismissed the speech as “theater.”
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
